comms: Not included in the database because Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
comms_internal: It is theoretically possible to insert issa “now” after the person name, cf. also “Shadi kān ʿind-o waǧaʿ rās” [PN was.3M.SG at-POSS.3M.SG pain(N) head] “Shadi had a headache”. Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”.

Same as 38. Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. The possessive suffix agrees with the experiencer. In the present tense, there is no overt copula. However, in the past tense, there will be an overt copula that does not agree with anything, cf. “ana kān ʿind-e influwanza” [I was.3M.SG at-POSS.1SG flu] ‘I had the flu’.

comms: Not included in the database because the intended meaning is expressed by a structurally discontinuous combination (predicate + adnominal modifier).
comms_internal: Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. Literally: ‘Shadi, with him (is/was) enough money’. The preposition bears the suffix that agrees with the possessor. Cf. “Ana maʿ-e kifāy maṣāre” [PN with-POSS.1.SG enough money] ‘I have enough money’. In the past tense, the copula is overt, cf. “Reem kān maʿ-ha kifāy maṣāre” [PN was.3M.SG with-POSS.3F.SG enough money] “Reem had enough money”.

Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. “ṣḥāb” is grammatically plural. Cf. “Reem kaan-at ṣḥāb ma' Shadi” [PN be.PST-3F.SG friend.PL with Shadi] ‘Reem was friends with Shadi’. ṣāḥeb = friend.M, ṣāḥbe - friend.F, ṣḥāb friend.PL.

Same as 2. Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. Same as in 2. The copula (e.g. in the past tense) does not agree with anything, preposition displays possessive agreement with the possessor.

back_translation_en: ‘Shadi is trying to catch a cat.’
comms_internal: Same as 18. Using the verb for catching without the verb “to try” results in some degree of unnaturalness.

back_translation_en: ‘Shadi is dreaming of a new a car.’

comms_internal: Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. Literally: ‘this tool its name compass’. The possessive affix shows the gender of the EXT argument (‘tool’). In the past tense, there would be a copula: “hāy il-ʾāle kān usom-ha būṣale” [this DEF-tool was.3M.SG name-POSS.3F.SG compass] ‘This tool was called a compass’, lit. ‘this tool was its name compass’. The copula kān does not agree with anything even in sentences like “His brothers’ name were Shadi and John”. The regular NP structure for the “name of X” is different, cf. “Nsīt usom hāy il-ʾāle” [Forget.PST.1SG name this DEF-tool] ‘I forgot (the) name (of) this tool’. The structure like “kān usom hāy il-ʾāle būṣale” is is technically possible, but the original version is more natural.

The classification is tentative and based on the observed form of the sentence. It is not natural to use non-lexical second argument here. The verb agrees with the bucket, which is masculine (the water is feminine).

The verb clearly agrees with the person name, as seen in the following example: “Reem nāʾiṣ-ha mīt dolar” [PN lack.PTCP-POSS.3F.SG hundred dollar] ‘Reem is short a 100 dollars’. In the past tense, the tense would be expressed by the overt copula, cf. “Shadi kān nāʾṣ-o dolar” [… was.3M.SG …] ‘Shadi lacked a dollar’.
Non-present clauses have an overt copula based on the root “k.ū.n”. Literally: Shadi (is) in need of money. The copula (when overt) agrees with X.
literally: 10 dollars remained with Bader. The verb agrees regularly with the Y-argument, cf. “ḍall-at maʿ Bader sayyara” [remain.PST-3F.SG with PN car] “Bader has a car left”.
Literally: my shirt is other your shirt.

comms_internal: CV. The fact that the Y-argument is syntactically an NP-internal dependent is clearly visible from the construction with a pronominal Y: “Shadi wiʾe bi-ḥob-i” [PN fall.PST.3M.SG in-love-POSS.1SG] ‘Shadi fell in love with me’.
